title: Preseason has failed to implement it's goals.
body:
When preseason 6 first came around I was aware that balance would be jeopardized for the next several patches but It's not just balance that is currently failing but most of Riots goals with these massive changes.

Rift Herald: How rarely is this thing even used. I mean its not game breaking or broken on its own but for most games it just sits their waiting to turn into Baron.

ADC Upgrade...oh sorry I meant Update: So if you aren't Lucian MF or Graves player then this update means very little to you. New items and better costs but Essence reaver makes the 3 listed champions as broken as RIven's sword. Sure there are new times but as always, there's the one build path which is best. No variety in style of build or champion choice.

Gameplay/Momentum: We've all experienced it. Games are short curb stomps or slaughters where one mistake by one teammate can screw over your chances of wining. The minion changes help slightly but now I feel as if I'm playing an over glorified Call of Duty game instead of a strategic team game. Get you ad assassin or marksmen fed is the new name for League.

Masteries: Good Lord. Instead of choice we have broken mastery of the week where you find out that these new masteries are better than most champion passives. The Warlord's rampage, thunder lords League etc. Not only are the masteries too synergetic with some champions while leaving others in the dust. Plus Swain, Anivia, and Karthus nerfs because of them? Really? Did we learn nothing from Warwick and Feral Flare or Sejuani and CInderhulk. Take you broken masteries back and give me the old ones which didn't dominate the game and make a subset of champions OP only for them to be nerfed when there are far worse balance cases.


Priorities and Plans have been bungled so much recently. The Juggernaut reign the 100% morde ban/pick. I haven't seen a positive change in so long I'm losing hope of what season 6 will be like. (Also new assassin item. Welcome back to the League of Zed mid-lane. At least Faker and Bjergsen will be happy.)

Change is good but change just for the sake of it, like this preseason, is just useless and poor design.

This is the fundamental issue when balancing ADC's. I feel as if people forget their greatest strength which is persistent damage from range. This means that as long as there are towers and objectives in League ADC's will have their place. ADC's as a class will always seem underpowered and unable to kill tanks or overpowered and shredding everyone because of how they are designed.

My problem with pre-season is that it seriously feels like all the progressions Riot made with Season 4 and 5 were completely dismissed.

I felt like in Seasons 4 and 5, everything was getting more balanced, everything headed ever so slightly towards a well balanced, fun, strategic game.

Now? Game might well be called Call of Legends, almost every game I play is decided by the 20 minute mark, no questions asked, whoever is ahead at 20 is going to be ahead until 50 minutes into the game.

Zephyr removed? Say good by the item niches/diversity you wanted. Cull? Why???

I have not had a game that wasn't TDM since preseason, strategy is gone, it is snowball to hell or you are going to be useless. The game is literally win your lane or never be effective, and there is an issue with that. Yes comebacks can always happen, people can throw leads, but it is damn hard to throw any lead you have because you have free reign over objectives, and unless the team that is behind has a shit load of sightstones/blue trinkets, you can't even walk into your jungle.

Remove stealth wards? WHy the fuck is that even an option that is considered? That is already a buff to assassins and burst champions in general, then buff thunderlords and a mastery that gives free pen? You wanted champion diversity, and if you don't pick into the META in this preseason you gave 75% chance of being worthless to your team, a 15% of being even and a 10% chance of actually being an asset to your team.

I have no idea what riot was thinking, literally if fall behind you will stay behind. What is wrong with long, drawn out games? are that much of an issue? is there an issue with your oh so precious early game champions falling off? Is there an issue with the fact that assassins shouldn't be able to kill tanks? You say you want to add comeback potential, yet at the same time back towers almost indefensible unless you are there before the enemy. 

Riot, you say you want to add diversity, yet you lessin it by your changes. There was more diversity early-mid season 5 then anytime after that. I am not saying cinderhulk was balanced by any means, but that was when the most champs were being played.

Riot, please, stop being hypocrites, I believe that any changes you have in mind at this point have to be major to recover from this for the start of the next season. I just don't see a reason to even try and complain this for the most part, because nothing ever changes with riot. They always annoy the community, and always go back to the times when flashy plays and kills are what is going on because that is what is fun to watch for most people.

I personally hate watching TDMs, I like the drawn out slugfests that we had. Yes, you probaly lost viewers for it, but at least their was less annoyance and who lot less rage at it.

well, the problem with really long games is that some team comps can simply rely on the fallback of stall-to-win. That takes some of the excitement out of it, at least for many spectators. Of course, supporting an environment of snowball-to-win is a bit counterintuitive if the issue to be eliminated was the catering to champions that could simply abuse their gold-dependant god phase. At least the snowball-to-win does actually reward and require more good, meaningful decision-making than stall-to-win, which is more reliant on less dynamic game elements. I like that the game is emphasizing growing upon small advantages and opportunities, at least it sounds good on paper. It even sounds like a good learning tool, however, it often seems to pan out in ways that are overly frustrating. People are people, and more often than not, one can count on them to make the most foolish and careless of mistakes. Here, those are forgiven far less easily than we may be accustomed to, but I think many people are overlooking the pro's (as in pro/con) to this environment of snowball. They do exist.
Why is it a problem if lategame teams get a chance to try & turtle up to lategame? You might as well not have lategame oriented champs if that's a problem.

For me personally, I don't see any pros to it then shorter games that are stomps more then close drawn out games. I find a game dependent on snowballing to be poorly designed because when about half your champions are reliant on at the very least three items, they become unviable to your team. Nasus is literally only slightly viable because he can 45% CDR, and the stall-to-win is still what those few games I don't have decided by 20 minutes are.

I am someone who despises anything that is reliant on getting kills to get ahead, any system designed that way is flawed. If I wanted to play a game designed that way I would play First Person Shooters, and I don't even see this new system punishing mistakes, in fact I am seeing less of it, because 75% of the top lane reliably-viable champions(such as Darius) don't care if they give up two kills, because in most matchups, him simply being that strong up until late mid game and into late. 

Another issue is an entirely personal. I like huge tanks(Sion/Maokai/Naut/Sej) and picking those champions other then sejuani is very set circumstances just straight up puts your team behind from the get go. When games are basically based around stuff that happens in the five-to-nine minutes, I see flaws. Mistakes that early, should not be strongly affecting what happens twenty minutes later unless there a ton of the deaths in that span, and yet, they do.

It is flawed to me, and more infuriating than entertaining.

Well I like what they did as far as trying to give each adc a unique identity, but MF in particular feels a little too oppressive with her unfairly long ranged slow, generally steroided abilities, and insane poke. She's a bit overtuned. 

The tank prowess that has arisen accidentally is a bit annoying. Unkillable Mundo's surface every game it seems, and it's exceedingly difficult to recover from the failures of other team mates to deal with them--at the very least, people could learn to lose their lane without feeding. 

I feel sad for mage mains, and as someone who often fills, I usually have to take on mid lane because it seems most people would rather not. This was not the case last season(seemed like support was least wanted role). I'm not complaining, as I'm still able to learn and have fun and prioritize objectives in order to accomplish victory. 

I'm not a fan of league of Thunderlords, or that masteries have been split up to give junglers a headache, but I'm not angry about it. I just wish Riot's purpose for them regarding meaningful desicions was not limited to "pick thunderlords or your team will hate you".

What I really, really, REALLY DESPISE about this new season is the vision nerf. I feel like I'm freaking blind all of the time, and heavily reliant on the support's ward placement. When I am the support, I feel a lot of the burden of vision come down to me. Everyone else uses blue trinket, not because it's so great, but because the alternative is garbage. So the answer wouldn't be to nerf blue trinkets, but to bring the other trinkets back to a good place. A dark map may be exciting to watch, but it isn't fun to play, and having been used to taking control of vision, it freaks me the fuck out. I feel frustrated playing top and mid.  Where I used to have such a good handle on my vision, and liberally used vision advantage to win  my lane confidently, I now shiver in place like a Chihuahua in December because I don't know what the fuck is going on around me. It's all very confusing because Riot's idea about season 6 and running theme was "meaningful decisions". What about the decision not to buy greens? Or the decision not to purchase a trinket upgrade? Or To purchase such things? were these not highly meaningful decisions that could win or lose games or otherwise severely impact the outcome? Were they not fine as they were? What decision do we have regarding trinkets now? What meaningful decisions do we have left regarding vision?

The Rift Herald is actually pretty good, especially on a lot of devourer junglers.

That additional, easy 5 stacks makes it a lot easier to get sated quickly.

The problem with it, at least so far, it's that it requires TWO players to take down, and the buff it gives only helps 1 player. Dragon it's still way more important than Gerald, plus it can be soloed by many junglers.

And it's mostly a snowballing buff, a "win harder" mechanic. I wont risk a 2 v 2 for Geral when top and I are behind, and wont ask mid to get slaughter too. So only the winning team gets the buff, which is really "unfair" in away, since it's not game breaking like Baron buff, and since you can only get it pre 20 min, it's only worth to extend the lead you got.

I'll rather risk dragon than Gerald, at least I know that if I take drag I can delay a potential 5th drag team, or 3rd drag with that amazing MS buff.

Yep. This is the issue for me, too.

If top is ahead, he doesn't need the herald.

If top is behind or about even, he doesn't _want_ the herald, because it'll force him to push (and become susceptible to ganks).

So I only bother with herald if it's wide open and will take basically no time at all to grab.

Although it works thematically, I think the pushing mechanic needs to be removed to make the herald more viable. It'd be much better if it granted sustain.

It certainly feels like they have pushed a lot of changes in order to make the game feel more fresh, but ultimately failed to make all adjustments required before season 6 start. Pretty similar to what happened back in preseason 4.

Some of these are legit complaints, but I really think you expect this game to be 100% balanced. That's never, ever, ever, ever, EVER GOING TO HAPPEN. EVER. No video game with multiple unique characters is going to be 100% balanced. Look at every fighting game and MMO ever. Something is always going to be better. What matters is that the game continues to change so different characters and roles get their turn. Look at the difference between season 5 spring and fall: it's practically a different game. Remember preseason 5 when only 2 jungles could do a full clear? There's no way in hell this is worse than that. 

Games needed to be shorter. That has been achieved and it has to do with overall changes to the game effecting teamwork, not adcs. Best improvement the game has made since its inception. 

Lucian, Tristana, Kalista, MF, Ashe, and even Vayne (despite having no certain item path) are solid picks right now. Graves is strong but not an every game adc. Caitlyn serves two roles: A safe option for non-adc mains who just want to farm and stay relevant in team fights without putting themselves in too much risk, and over aggressive early game styles where you want to keep bot lane pushed hard. Jinx and Sivir are only hurting because games don't last long enough for them to really put on the hurt anymore, but are still decent picks. Kog and Draven are the two really in need of help. I have no idea about Ez -- he's a good early game lane bully in the right hands but he either falls off hard mid game or has to put himself at too much risk in team fights. 

Lucian might seem op, but he's far easier to deal with than he was in season 4. 

Masteries are way better. Even if they don't balance out thunderlords. Still way better. Actual choices. No longer just doing their best impression of wow masteries. The sacrifices you make for utility and defense are actually fair and not gutting to the whole laning phase. Supports can actually build some damage and god help be a little more fun to play without completely f'ing over your adc. Thunderlords does need to be looked at, but even if they made no changes for season 6 it's a way bigger improvement over past masteries.
Hey, Hey, it wasn't only 2 jungles that could do a full clear. {{champion:19}} {{champion:9}} {{champion:5}} {{champion:11}}  could. that's 4

Rift Herald is extremely important, especially for devourer junglers. Adds +5 stacks, and it's a very good objective to play around. Top lane is less of an island now, which is much better.

ADC upgrade also threw out the reign of {{champion:222}}  and {{champion:67}} , both who were much more cancerous than MF and Lucian. Quinn, Trist, Corki, Twitch, also got very much needed changes, especially the former. Variety in bot lane is far better than it was before, Urgot and Kog are the only ADCs I have seen little of. 

The game punishes mistakes far more now, which I think is a lot better. Teaches idiots not to try and take enemy red after taking inhib at 40 minutes. Lane phases, especially top, are far more interesting than the average 20 minute farm fest it used to be. 

6 Masteries are already in plan to receive buffs, and it will almost certainly change before season 6 comes out. Masteries before were stale as shit and were unnoticeable for the majority of their time. Swain/Anivia/Karthus nerfs had nothing to do with masteries either. 

Juggernauts are not ban/pick anymore... Assassin item hasn't even been released yet, so calm the fuck down.

And no good changes? Poppy rework, revamped champion select on the way, stop talking bullshit.

Quinn, Trist, Corki, Twitch, also got very much needed changes, especially the former. Variety in bot lane is far better than it was before, Urgot and Kog are the only ADCs I have seen little of. 

Right now the problem I have with ADCs is how clear the A and B tier ADCs are. The top 5 ADCs are Lucian, Vayne, MF, Jinx and Trist. You could argue that Corki is also up there, personally I'd say he's a solid sixth place, he's better than the rest of the ADCs but isn't quite as good as these 5.

After these 6 ADCs fall off super hard. I very rarely see ADCs like Ashe, Twitch, Sivir, Draven ect. These guys just seem to have fallen off the face of the earth.

Sure, at the top end ADCs have better variance, but in the mid range there's just a huge gap between the ADCs who are actually good and who just aren't good enough.

Cait is in a good spot, Twitch is considered good by pros who use him like Dlift, Sivir is the same. You forget also forget to mention Ezreal and Kali (the latter is very common in higher elo).

The only ADC who I've seen dropped in play rate after the patch is Draven (and the rarely seen anyways Kog). I don't see many of them, but minion block is considered a huge problem by most of them when trying to axe catch.
